guide.conclusion:
Mods

This catapult launcher is a rough replica of the one used by the U.S. military, so while it folds, it’s still not very portable. I challenge MAKE readers to come up with more compact and clever designs and share them here. The possibilities are endless!

This project first appeared in MAKE Volume 32, page 104.

guide.introduction:
For many years, the U.S. military has enjoyed playing with “toys.”

Today that includes unmanned drone aircraft, but in the past, it was toy balsa wood airplanes. Thousands of folding-wing balsa gliders were shot out of the sky in the early 1940s for World War II artillery practice. High in the air, these toy airplanes had the scale effect of a full-sized plane. Developed and patented in 1939 by Jim Walker, founder of the American Junior Aircraft Company, the folding-wing Army Interceptor glider bore the brunt of the action.

My folding-wing Rocket Glider, based on the Interceptor, was featured as a how-to project in MAKE Volume 31 and is available as a kit from Maker Shed. While the Interceptor originally used a handheld rubber-band catapult, the military designed a launcher to hurl the gliders nearly 300 feet high. In 2004, Frank Macy designed the first reproduction of this launcher, on which this project is based.

With nearly 20 pounds of pulling force, this simple catapult remarkably flings the tiny glider (weighing less than an ounce) 150 feet into the air. Stand clear, pull the rope trigger, and watch a piece of history rocket into the sky!

lines.text: Assemble the tripod stand, following the assembly drawings (Step 1). Cut the top inside corners of the 2 front legs at 15° so they’ll meet the rear leg flush when they’re splayed out.
lines.text_raw: Assemble the tripod stand, following the assembly drawings (Step 1). Cut the top inside corners of the 2 front legs at 15° so they’ll meet the rear leg flush when they’re splayed out.

lines.text: Drill 1/4" holes where indicated, then attach the pieces with 1/4" bolts, washers, and nuts, except the 30" launch platform (see Step 3).
lines.text_raw: Drill 1/4" holes where indicated, then attach the pieces with 1/4" bolts, washers, and nuts, except the 30" launch platform (see Step 3).

lines.text: Use wing nuts at the top of the tripod (with a 4" bolt) and where the catapult arms attach to the rear leg (5-1/2" bolt). This way, the catapult arms can be loosened and swung back so the launcher is more portable.
lines.text_raw: Use wing nuts at the top of the tripod (with a 4" bolt) and where the catapult arms attach to the rear leg (5-1/2" bolt). This way, the catapult arms can be loosened and swung back so the launcher is more portable.

lines.text: Attach one screw eye 3' up on the rear leg, and another on the upper rail that supports the launch platform. Measure 33" of chain and attach it to both screw eyes.
lines.text_raw: Attach one screw eye 3' up on the rear leg, and another on the upper rail that supports the launch platform. Measure 33" of chain and attach it to both screw eyes.

lines.text: Drill 1/2" holes horizontally through the free ends of the catapult arms.
lines.text_raw: Drill 1/2" holes horizontally through the free ends of the catapult arms.

lines.text: Cut the aluminum C-channel to 26"  using a hacksaw. Following the diagram, place the channel, open side up, in the center of the 1×4 board, 2" from the top. Drill pilot holes through the channel and attach it with 3/4" wood screws.
lines.text_raw: Cut the aluminum C-channel to 26"  using a hacksaw. Following the diagram, place the channel, open side up, in the center of the 1×4 board, 2" from the top. Drill pilot holes through the channel and attach it with 3/4" wood screws.

lines.text: Measure down 14-1/4" from the top of  the 1×4, then drill two 1/4" holes 1-1/2" apart (on center), one on each side of the channel.
lines.text_raw: Measure down 14-1/4" from the top of  the 1×4, then drill two 1/4" holes 1-1/2" apart (on center), one on each side of the channel.

lines.text: To install the wing holder, cut a 10" piece of wire from a clothes hanger and bend it into the shape shown in the photo. Then screw it into the launch platform 8-1/4" below the 1/4" holes you made. Placement is important; it must hold the Rocket Glider’s wings back, but not impede it from leaving the launcher.

Then screw it into the launch platform 8-1/4" below the 1/4" holes you made. Placement is important; it must hold the Rocket Glider’s wings back, but not impede it from leaving the launcher.

lines.text: If you’ll be launching some other craft, don’t install the wing holder yet; wait until you build the trigger mechanism in the next step so you can get your measurements right.
lines.text_raw: If you’ll be launching some other craft, don’t install the wing holder yet; wait until you build the trigger mechanism in the next step so you can get your measurements right.

lines.text: Attach a screw eye centered in the bottom edge of the launch platform; this will guide the trigger cord.
lines.text_raw: Attach a screw eye centered in the bottom edge of the launch platform; this will guide the trigger cord.

lines.text: Finally, mount the launch platform centered on the lower horizontal rails on the tripod stand, using wood screws.
lines.text_raw: Finally, mount the launch platform centered on the lower horizontal rails on the tripod stand, using wood screws.

lines.text: Glue and screw the 3" piece of 1×2  horizontally to the top of the 17" piece of 1×2. Drill two 3/32" or 1/8" holes in the horizontal piece, 1-1/2" apart, so the 1/8" rod will fit snugly.
lines.text_raw: Glue and screw the 3" piece of 1×2  horizontally to the top of the 17" piece of 1×2. Drill two 3/32" or 1/8" holes in the horizontal piece, 1-1/2" apart, so the 1/8" rod will fit snugly.

lines.text: Bend the 1/8" rod into a U shape with  4" legs, 1-1/2" wide at the base. Carefully  hammer the U-shaped rod all the way into the 2 holes so they stick out the other side about 3". These are the trigger rods.
lines.text_raw: Bend the 1/8" rod into a U shape with  4" legs, 1-1/2" wide at the base. Carefully  hammer the U-shaped rod all the way into the 2 holes so they stick out the other side about 3". These are the trigger rods.

lines.text: Drill a 1/2" hole through the bottom of  the trigger board and tie the launch cord through it.
lines.text_raw: Drill a 1/2" hole through the bottom of  the trigger board and tie the launch cord through it.

lines.text: IMPORTANT: Make sure the trigger rods are the same length, so they’ll release the glider at the same time.
lines.text_raw: '''IMPORTANT:''' Make sure the trigger rods  are the same length, so they’ll release the glider at the same time.

lines.text: Feed the trigger rods through the 1/4" holes in the launch platform. Attach 2 wood screws into the sides of the launch platform and stretch a rubber band between them to hold the trigger board in place. The 2 pins should move easily in and out of the holes in the launch platform. Bend them if you need to.

Attach 2 wood screws into the sides of the launch platform and stretch a rubber band between them to hold the trigger board in place. The 2 pins should move easily in and out of the holes in the launch platform. Bend them if you need to.

lines.text: When you’re satisfied with the trigger action, attach the T-hinge to the trigger board and the bottom rail.
lines.text_raw: When you’re satisfied with the trigger action, attach the T-hinge to the trigger board and the bottom rail.

lines.text: Feed the trigger cord through the screw eye in the bottom of the launch platform.
lines.text_raw: Feed the trigger cord through the screw eye in the bottom of the launch platform.

lines.text: Cut the surgical tubing into two 3' lengths and tie a big knot in one end of each. Feed these through the 1/2" holes in the ends of the catapult arms.
lines.text_raw: Cut the surgical tubing into two 3' lengths and tie a big knot in one end of each. Feed these through the 1/2" holes in the ends of the catapult arms.

lines.text: Cut a 24" length of the heavy coated wire and tie a knot in each end. Tie the wire into the free ends of each length of surgical tubing. You’re done.
lines.text_raw: Cut a 24" length of the heavy coated wire and tie a knot in each end. Tie the wire into the free ends of each length of surgical tubing. You’re done.

lines.text: Set up your launcher on a good-sized field with little or no wind. With the catapult arms in launch position, tighten the wing nuts.
lines.text_raw: Set up your launcher on a good-sized field with little or no wind. With the catapult arms in launch position, tighten the wing nuts.

lines.text: Pull the surgical tubing downward and  hook the catapult wire onto the trigger rods. The tubing should be pointing straight up vertically.
lines.text_raw: Pull the surgical tubing downward and  hook the catapult wire onto the trigger rods. The tubing should be pointing straight up vertically.

lines.text: Now practice triggering the catapult without the glider. With your head well clear, place one foot on the catapult cross-rail, and slowly pull the rope back, triggering the catapult. Don’t jerk it, or the trigger can bounce back and damage your glider.
lines.text_raw: Now practice triggering the catapult  without the glider. With your head well clear, place one foot on the catapult cross-rail, and ''slowly'' pull the rope back, triggering the catapult. Don’t jerk it, or the trigger can bounce back and damage your glider.

lines.text: This is an extremely powerful catapult to launch a glider that weighs barely 1oz. There is room for disaster. I suggest practice-launching something else before you move on to the glider.
lines.text_raw: This is an extremely powerful catapult to launch a glider that weighs barely 1oz. There is room for disaster. I suggest practice-launching something else before you move on to the glider.

lines.text: Now for the true test. With the wings folded back, place the glider in the C-channel, and hook the launch notch in the bottom of the glider onto the catapult wire. The folded wings should slip freely into the wire wing holder.

lines.text: Just like the U.S. Army did 70 years ago with a similar launcher, pull the rope slowly ... and watch your glider zip skyward.
